DOC.HEAD: Charge Dismissed in Alleged Plot to Kill Mayor
DOC.TEXT: A judge has dismissed charges against a 75-year-old anti-tax crusader accused of plotting earlier this year to kill then-Mayor Henry Cisneros, ruling the defendant had been entrapped. Parker Abell, 75, had been charged with solicitation of capital murder, accused of offering a district attorney's investigator $5,000 in May for Cisneros' slaying. Cisneros did not seek re-election and left office in June. Defense attorney Steve Hilbig argued that it was investigator John Veltkamp, not Abell, who was doing the persuading during their videotaped meeting in May, and District Judge Mike Machado agreed Monday that Abell was entrapped. ``It's an early Christmas present for Mr. Abell,'' said Hilbig, a former assistant U.S. attorney seeking the Republican nomination for district attorney. ``That's what they should have done,'' Abell told his lawyer and the judge. Assistant District Attorney Julian Lopez said the law on entrapment is broad and that there was room for other interpretations, but he doubted prosecutors would pursue the case against the cancer-stricken Abell, a retired railroad employee from Natalia. ``I imagine that would be a factor in whether we appeal,'' Lopez said. ``He's old. He's very sick.'' Abell, who officials said had not paid taxes for 10 years, is a one-time Libertarian candidate for Congress. Hilbig said he believes the investigation of Abell was initiated by the Internal Revenue Service in 1988 after Abell called into a radio talk show to complain about rising taxes. According to testimony, the IRS paid an informant $1,000 in advance to develop information on Abell.
